notes.text:
Red Hat JBoss Core Services Apache HTTP Server 2.4.57 Service Pack 4 is now available.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Moderate. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Red Hat JBoss Core Services is a set of supplementary software for Red Hat JBoss middleware products. This software, such as Apache HTTP Server, is common to multiple JBoss middleware products and packaged under Red Hat JBoss Core Services, to allow for faster distribution of updates and for a more consistent update experience.

This release of Red Hat JBoss Core Services Apache HTTP Server 2.4.57 Service Pack 4 serves as a replacement for Red Hat JBoss Core Services Apache HTTP Server 2.4.57 Service Pack 3, and includes bug fixes and enhancements, which are documented in the Release Notes linked to in the References section.

Security Fix(es):

* curl: Usage of disabled protocol (CVE-2024-2004)
* curl: QUIC certificate check bypass with wolfSSL (CVE-2024-2379)
* curl: HTTP/2 push headers memory-leak (CVE-2024-2398)
* curl: TLS certificate check bypass with mbedTLS (CVE-2024-2466)
* jbcs-httpd24-httpd: httpd: CONTINUATION frames DoS (CVE-2024-27316)
* jbcs-httpd24-mod_http2: httpd: CONTINUATION frames DoS (CVE-2024-27316)
* jbcs-httpd24-nghttp2: httpd: CONTINUATION frames DoS (CVE-2024-27316)
* jbcs-httpd24-nghttp2: nghttp2: CONTINUATION frames DoS (CVE-2024-28182)

A Red Hat Security Bulletin which addresses further details about this flaw is available in the References section.

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

notes.text: A flaw was found in curl. When a protocol selection parameter disables all protocols without adding any, the default set of protocols remains in the allowed set due to a logic error, allowing usage of disabled protocols.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: curl: Usage of disabled protocol
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The curl package as shipped in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, 7, 8, 9, and RHSCL is not affected by this vulnerability because the vulnerable code was introduced in a newer version of curl.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata relevant to your system have been applied.

For details on how to apply this update, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

notes.text: A flaw was found in curl. When libcurl is built to use wolfSSL as the TLS backend, it skips certificate verification for a QUIC connection if an unknown/bad cipher or curve is used.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: curl: QUIC certificate check bypass with wolfSSL
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The curl package as shipped by Red Hat Enterprise Linux and RHSCL is not affected by this vulnerability because it does not have support for wolfSSL.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata relevant to your system have been applied.

For details on how to apply this update, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: curl: QUIC certificate check bypass with wolfSSL

cwe.name: Missing Release of Resource after Effective Lifetime

notes.text: A flaw was found in curl. When an application configures libcurl to use HTTP/2 server push and the amount of received headers for the push surpasses the maximum allowed limit, libcurl aborts the server push. When aborting, libcurl does not free all the previously allocated headers, resulting in a memory leak.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: curl: HTTP/2 push headers memory-leak
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata relevant to your system have been applied.

For details on how to apply this update, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

cwe.name: Improper Validation of Certificate with Host Mismatch

notes.text: A flaw was found in curl. When curl is built to use mbedTLS as the TLS backend, it does not check the server certificate of TLS connections done to a host specified as an IP address.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: curl: TLS certificate check bypass with mbedTLS
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The curl package as shipped by Red Hat Enterprise Linux and RHSCL is not affected by this vulnerability because it does not have support for mbedTLS.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata relevant to your system have been applied.

For details on how to apply this update, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: curl: TLS certificate check bypass with mbedTLS

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in how Apache httpd implements the HTTP/2 protocol. There are insufficient limitations placed on the amount of CONTINUATION frames that can be sent within a single stream. This issue could allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to send packets to vulnerable servers, which could use up memory resources to cause a Denial of Service.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: CONTINUATION frames DoS
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text:
Red Hat rates the security impact of this vulnerability as Moderate, in alignment with upstream Apache. The worst case scenario is memory exhaustion causing a denial of service. Once an attack has ended, the system should return to normal operations on its own.

This vulnerability stems from an imperfect definition of the HTTP/2 protocol. As the httpd component is widely utilized across nearly every major Red Hat offering, a full listing of impacted packages will not be provided. Therefore, the âAffected Packages and Issued Red Hat Security Errataâ section contains a simplified list of what offerings need to remediate this vulnerability. Every impacted offering has at least one representative component listed, but potentially not all of them.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata relevant to your system have been applied.

For details on how to apply this update, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
Red Hat has investigated whether a possible mitigation exists for this issue, and has not been able to identify a practical example. Please update the affected package as soon as possible.

cwe.name: Detection of Error Condition Without Action

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in how nghttp2 implements the HTTP/2 protocol. There are insufficient limitations placed on the amount of CONTINUATION frames that can be sent within a single stream. This issue could allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to send packets to vulnerable servers, which could use up compute or memory resources to cause a Denial of Service.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: nghttp2: CONTINUATION frames DoS
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat rates the security impact of this vulnerability as Moderate, in alignment with upstream nghttp2. The worst case scenario is excessive CPU utilization causing a denial of service. Once an attack has ended, the system should return to normal operations on its own.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata relevant to your system have been applied.

For details on how to apply this update, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
Red Hat has investigated whether a possible mitigation exists for this issue, and has not been able to identify a practical example. Please update the affected package as soon as possible.
